text: U.K. RETAILERS SEE GROWTH IN CONSUMER SPENDING. U.K. Retailers expect consumer spending to accelerate in March after a disappointing increase in February, according to a monthly survey by the Confederation of British Industry (CBI). Fifty-nine pct of the 325 retailers questioned for the latest Distributive Trades Survey expected sales to be higher in March than they were in March 1986, with only six pct expecting lower sales. The chairman of the Distributive Trades Survey Panel, Nigel Whittaker, said a favourable Budget next week would further help sales during the summer. Figures released earlier this week showed retail sales in January fell 2.2 pct, mainly due to exceptionally cold weather. "Sales did not recover in February as much as retailers had expected, and they are now looking for better business in March," today's survey said. It reported clothing stores were the most optimistic, with 80 pct expecting sales in March to be higher than a year ago. Wholesalers also expected stronger sales in March, while both retailers and wholesalers reported slower growth in import penetration, it said.

text: USDA TO CONDUCT SURVEY FOR AVIAN INFLUENZA. U.S. Agriculture Department animal health officials are conducting a national survey of live-bird markets and auctions to check for signs of avian influenza, an infectious viral disease of poultry, the department said. The survey will locate poultry dealers and live-bird markets that sell live birds directly to the consumer and once the dealers and markets are identified, there will be tests to determine any past or present exposure to avian influenza viruses, it said. In 1983-84, an outbreak of avian influenza in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia and New Jersey cost taxpayers 65 mln dlrs to control and required the destruction of more than 17 mln birds, it said. The survey is expected to be completed by April 15.

text: ANTIBIOTICS IN FEED AID DEADLY BACTERIA: STUDY. A study of salmonella poisoning has uncovered new evidence that the common practice of feeding antibiotics to cattle is helping to create deadly bacteria that can infect humans and resist medicines. Researchers at the federal Centers for Disease Control tracked the spread of an unusual strain of salmonella that is resistant to the drug chloramphenicol and were able to link the resulting food poisoning to farms that used the drug to promote the growth of cattle. Cattlemen often give their animals a constant supply of antibiotics in feed to help them grow faster. But critics have been warning for years that the constant exposure to the drugs is helping bacteria learn to resist the drugs. Industry officials have disputed this, saying the diseases that develop a resistance in cattle probably do not affect humans. But the new study, reported in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine, shows the diseases can spread to humans. The research team, led by Dr. John Spika, said the number of people who have developed the chloramphenicol-resistant infection in Los Angeles County alone jumped from 69 in 1984 to 298 the following year. Two of those victims died and half the victims in their study of 45 patients had to be hospitalized for their illness. They also discovered that cooking the meat didn't always prevent the disease. Only 15 pct of the victims reported eating raw, infected hamburger. Thus, the researchers concluded, "the majority of cases appear to have been caused by eating hamburger that was at least partially cooked." The researchers said the results show that "food animals are a major source of antimicrobial-resistant salmonella infections in humans, and that these infections are associated with (antibiotic) use on farms."
rationale: The news story is about a study that has found a link between the use of antibiotics in cattle feed and the development of antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria, such as salmonella, that can infect humans. The researchers were able to trace the spread of a particular strain of salmonella that is resistant to a specific drug, chloramphenicol, back to farms that used the drug in their cattle feed. The story discusses the implications of these findings for public health and the livestock industry.The topic that best fits this news story from the provided list is "livestock". The story is primarily about practices in the livestock industry (specifically, the use of antibiotics in cattle feed) and their potential impact on human health. Therefore, "livestock" is the most appropriate choice.

text: U.S. TALLOW PRODUCTION AND STOCKS. U.S. factory production of inedible tallow and grease amounted to 421.5 mln lbs in February, vs a revised 471.5 mln lbs the previous month and 419.2 mln lbs in the year-ago period, the Census Bureau said. The bureau placed February factory production of edible tallow at 96.9 mln lbs, vs a revised 111.4 mln lbs the previous month and 122.7 mln lbs in February a year earlier. It estimated factory and warehouse stocks of inedible tallow on February 28 at 410.7 mln lbs, vs a revised 351.6 mln the previous month and 361.9 mln in February, 1986. End-Feb stocks of edible tallow amounted to 41.9 mln lbs, vs a revised 40.1 mln lbs and 48.6 mln lbs in their respective periods. Factory consumption of inedible tallow and grease in February was assessed at 238.3 mln lbs, vs a revised 250.4 mln lbs a month earlier and 220.5 mln lbs in the year-ago period. During February, factories used 65.3 mln lbs of edible tallow, vs a revised 71.8 mln and 84.6 mln, respectively. Total factory production and consumption of tallow in the 1987 marketing season, which began Jan 1, vs the 1986 season, were as follows, in mln lbs -- Production -- 1987     1986 Inedible    893.0    920.1 Edible    208.3    274.7 Consumption -- Inedible    488.7    473.7 Edible    137.1    176.4
rationale: The news story is about the production, stocks, and consumption of inedible and edible tallow in the U.S. Tallow is a rendered form of beef or mutton fat, primarily made up of triglycerides. It is solid at room temperature. It is used in animal feed, to make soap, for cooking, in biofuel and as a bird food. The story does not fit into any of the specific topics provided. However, considering that tallow is used in animal feed, the closest topic could be "livestock". The story provides data on the production and consumption of tallow, which could be relevant to those involved in the livestock industry, as it could impact the availability and price of animal feed. Therefore, the topic for this news story could be "livestock".

text: STORM BRINGS HEAVY SNOWS TO U.S. PLAINS. The National Weather Service said a powerful winter storm centered over north central Oklahoma was spreading snow from western and central Kansas across much of Nebraska to southern and eastern South Dakota. Rain was reported across parts of Minnesota, Iowa, eastern Kansas, Missouri and eastern Oklahoma, with showers and a few thundershowers extending from Arkansas through the lower Mississippi Valley to Alabama and northwest Florida. Strong winds of 20 to 35 mph with some stronger gusts were reported across much of the Plains, causing considerable blowingand drifting snow. A blizzard warning continued this morning across most of western Kansas. A winter storm warning was issued this morning over central and northeast Nebraska. Weather advisories were posted for this morning over central Kansas and central and southeast sections of South Dakota where two to five inches of snow could accumulate. Locally heavy rains accompanied the storm over portions of the central Plains. Flash flood watches were issued for this morning across the eastern half of Kansas. A flood warning continues today for eastern Nebraska. Widespread lowland and small stream flooding is expected to continue over most of eastern Nebraska through Wednesday. Due to cold, damp and windy conditions, livestock advisories were posted this morning across central and southeast portions of South Dakota. As the storm moves north across the central Plains, winter storm watches were issued over south central South Dakota, late tonight and Wednesday over west central Minnesota. Elsewhere, a travelers advisory remains in effect this morning over northeast New Mexico and the Oklahoma and Tecas Panhandle for blowing snow and slick roadways and across the mountains and deserts of southern California for strong gusty winds of 25 to 40 mph. Gale warnings were issued for today along the central California Coast. Mostly clear skies extended from the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley through the central Appalachians to the central Atlantic Coast and New England.

A blizzard warning continued this morning across most of western Kansas. A winter storm warning was issued this morning over central and northeast Nebraska. Weather advisories were posted for this morning over central Kansas and central and southeast sections of South Dakota where two to five inches of snow could accumulate. Locally heavy rains accompanied the storm over portions of the central Plains. Flash flood watches were issued for this morning across the eastern half of Kansas. A flood warning continues today for eastern Nebraska. Widespread lowland and small stream flooding is expected to continue over most of eastern Nebraska through Wednesday. Due to cold, damp and windy conditions, livestock advisories were posted this morning across central and southeast portions of South Dakota. As the storm moves north across the central Plains, winter storm watches were issued over south central South Dakota, late tonight and Wednesday over west central Minnesota. Elsewhere, a travelers advisory remains in effect this morning over northeast New Mexico and the Oklahoma and Tecas Panhandle for blowing snow and slick roadways and across the mountains and deserts of southern California for strong gusty winds of 25 to 40 mph. Gale warnings were issued for today along the central California Coast. Mostly clear skies extended from the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley through the central Appalachians to the central Atlantic Coast and New England.

text: USDA REPORTS RISE IN LIVESTOCK EXPORTS TO ASIA. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has reported a significant increase in livestock exports to Asian markets, particularly China and Japan, in the first quarter of 2022. The report indicates a 15% rise in beef exports and a 12% increase in pork exports compared to the same period last year. The USDA attributes this growth to the easing of trade restrictions and the growing demand for high-quality meat products in these markets. The department also noted that the ongoing efforts to improve animal health standards and breeding practices have contributed to the positive reception of U.S. livestock products abroad. However, the USDA cautioned that the global supply chain disruptions and rising feed costs could pose challenges to maintaining this upward trend in the coming months.

text: U.S. TALLOW PRODUCTION AND STOCKS. U.S. factory production of inedible tallow and grease amounted to 421.5 mln lbs in February, vs a revised 471.5 mln lbs the previous month and 419.2 mln lbs in the year-ago period, the Census Bureau said. The bureau placed February factory production of edible tallow at 96.9 mln lbs, vs a revised 111.4 mln lbs the previous month and 122.7 mln lbs in February a year earlier. It estimated factory and warehouse stocks of inedible tallow on February 28 at 410.7 mln lbs, vs a revised 351.6 mln the previous month and 361.9 mln in February, 1986. End-Feb stocks of edible tallow amounted to 41.9 mln lbs, vs a revised 40.1 mln lbs and 48.6 mln lbs in their respective periods. Factory consumption of inedible tallow and grease in February was assessed at 238.3 mln lbs, vs a revised 250.4 mln lbs a month earlier and 220.5 mln lbs in the year-ago period. During February, factories used 65.3 mln lbs of edible tallow, vs a revised 71.8 mln and 84.6 mln, respectively. Total factory production and consumption of tallow in the 1987 marketing season, which began Jan 1, vs the 1986 season, were as follows, in mln lbs -- Production -- 1987     1986 Inedible    893.0    920.1 Edible    208.3    274.7 Consumption -- Inedible    488.7    473.7 Edible    137.1    176.4
rationale: The news story is about the production, stocks, and consumption of inedible and edible tallow in the U.S. Tallow is a rendered form of beef or mutton fat, primarily made up of triglycerides. It is solid at room temperature. It is used in animal feed, to make soap, for cooking, in cosmetics, and as a biofuel. The story does not fit into any of the specific topics provided such as copper, livestock, gold, money-fx, tea, etc. However, considering that tallow is a byproduct of the meat industry and is used in animal feed, the closest topic would be 'livestock'. The story provides data on the production and consumption of tallow, which could impact the livestock industry. For instance, changes in the production of tallow could affect the availability and price of animal feed. Therefore, 'livestock' seems to be the most appropriate topic for this news story.

An additional 7,199 head of dairy cattle are still available to Egypt under the Export Enhancement Program initiative announced September 12, 1986, the department said.

text: ANTIBIOTICS IN FEED AID DEADLY BACTERIA: STUDY. A study of salmonella poisoning has uncovered new evidence that the common practice of feeding antibiotics to cattle is helping to create deadly bacteria that can infect humans and resist medicines. Researchers at the federal Centers for Disease Control tracked the spread of an unusual strain of salmonella that is resistant to the drug chloramphenicol and were able to link the resulting food poisoning to farms that used the drug to promote the growth of cattle. Cattlemen often give their animals a constant supply of antibiotics in feed to help them grow faster. But critics have been warning for years that the constant exposure to the drugs is helping bacteria learn to resist the drugs. Industry officials have disputed this, saying the diseases that develop a resistance in cattle probably do not affect humans. But the new study, reported in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine, shows the diseases can spread to humans. The research team, led by Dr. John Spika, said the number of people who have developed the chloramphenicol-resistant infection in Los Angeles County alone jumped from 69 in 1984 to 298 the following year. Two of those victims died and half the victims in their study of 45 patients had to be hospitalized for their illness. They also discovered that cooking the meat didn't always prevent the disease. Only 15 pct of the victims reported eating raw, infected hamburger. Thus, the researchers concluded, "the majority of cases appear to have been caused by eating hamburger that was at least partially cooked." The researchers said the results show that "food animals are a major source of antimicrobial-resistant salmonella infections in humans, and that these infections are associated with (antibiotic) use on farms."
rationale: The news story is about a study that has found a link between the use of antibiotics in cattle feed and the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria that can infect humans. The topic does not directly fall under any of the given categories like copper, gold, money-fx, etc. However, considering the context and content of the story, it can be categorized under 'livestock' as it primarily deals with practices related to cattle rearing and its implications on human health. The story does not discuss any financial or economic aspects, trade, or specific commodities other than livestock. Therefore, 'livestock' is the most appropriate topic for this news story.

text: USDA LAUNCHES NEW LIVESTOCK TRACEABILITY PROGRAM. The U.S. Department of Agriculture has announced the launch of a new livestock traceability program aimed at improving disease control among the nation's livestock population. The program will involve the tagging of cattle, swine, and sheep with electronic identification devices, allowing for rapid and accurate tracking of animals in the event of a disease outbreak. The USDA said the program will not only enhance the ability to respond to disease outbreaks but also boost consumer confidence in the safety of the U.S. meat supply. The program, which is set to begin in the fall, will be funded through a combination of federal and state resources. The USDA also noted that the program will be voluntary for livestock producers, but those who participate will have access to certain benefits, including expedited interstate movement of their animals. The announcement comes amid growing concerns about the potential for disease outbreaks in the livestock industry, including African swine fever and avian influenza.
rationale: The news story is labeled as "livestock" because it primarily discusses a new program launched by the U.S. Department of Agriculture that is directly related to the livestock industry. The program involves the tagging and tracking of livestock animals such as cattle, swine, and sheep for disease control purposes. The story also discusses the implications of this program for livestock producers and the potential benefits it offers, such as boosting consumer confidence in the safety of the U.S. meat supply and providing expedited interstate movement of animals for participating producers. Therefore, the main subject of the news story is the livestock industry, which justifies the "livestock" label.

text: AMERICAN PORK CONGRESS TO BE OVERHAULED IN 1988. The National Pork Producers Council, NPPC, announced at this year's American Pork Congress, APC, that the Congress and trade show will be divided into two parts in 1988. Next years APC, held in Atlanta, will be a business session only and will continue to be the first week of March. The trade show is being changed into a new international event called the World Pork Expo. The first expo will be held in June 1988 in Des Moines with an expanded format, they said. Executive vice-president Orville Sweet said the decision to spilt the show and Congress came about because there are producers who never get to see the trade show floor. "It makes sense that we divide the business session from the trade show," Sweet said.

text: STORM BRINGS HEAVY SNOWS TO U.S. PLAINS. The National Weather Service said a powerful winter storm centered over north central Oklahoma was spreading snow from western and central Kansas across much of Nebraska to southern and eastern South Dakota. Rain was reported across parts of Minnesota, Iowa, eastern Kansas, Missouri and eastern Oklahoma, with showers and a few thundershowers extending from Arkansas through the lower Mississippi Valley to Alabama and northwest Florida. Strong winds of 20 to 35 mph with some stronger gusts were reported across much of the Plains, causing considerable blowingand drifting snow. A blizzard warning continued this morning across most of western Kansas. A winter storm warning was issued this morning over central and northeast Nebraska. Weather advisories were posted for this morning over central Kansas and central and southeast sections of South Dakota where two to five inches of snow could accumulate. Locally heavy rains accompanied the storm over portions of the central Plains. Flash flood watches were issued for this morning across the eastern half of Kansas. A flood warning continues today for eastern Nebraska. Widespread lowland and small stream flooding is expected to continue over most of eastern Nebraska through Wednesday. Due to cold, damp and windy conditions, livestock advisories were posted this morning across central and southeast portions of South Dakota. As the storm moves north across the central Plains, winter storm watches were issued over south central South Dakota, late tonight and Wednesday over west central Minnesota. Elsewhere, a travelers advisory remains in effect this morning over northeast New Mexico and the Oklahoma and Tecas Panhandle for blowing snow and slick roadways and across the mountains and deserts of southern California for strong gusty winds of 25 to 40 mph. Gale warnings were issued for today along the central California Coast. Mostly clear skies extended from the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley through the central Appalachians to the central Atlantic Coast and New England.
rationale: Based on the content of the news story, the most appropriate topic to assign would be "weather." However, "weather" is not one of the available options in the provided set of topics. text: USDA LAUNCHES NEW LIVESTOCK TRACEABILITY PROGRAM. The U.S. Department of Agriculture has announced the launch of a new livestock traceability program aimed at improving disease control among the nation's livestock population. The program will involve the tagging of cattle, swine, and sheep with electronic identification devices, allowing for rapid and accurate tracking of animals in the event of a disease outbreak. The USDA said the program will not only enhance the ability to respond to disease outbreaks but also boost consumer confidence in the safety of the U.S. meat supply. The program, which is set to begin in the fall, will be funded through a combination of federal and state resources. The USDA also noted that the program will be voluntary for livestock producers, but those who participate will have access to certain benefits, including expedited interstate movement of their animals. The announcement comes amid growing concerns about the potential for disease outbreaks in the livestock industry, including African swine fever and avian influenza.

text: U.S. TALLOW PRODUCTION AND STOCKS. U.S. factory production of inedible tallow and grease amounted to 421.5 mln lbs in February, vs a revised 471.5 mln lbs the previous month and 419.2 mln lbs in the year-ago period, the Census Bureau said. The bureau placed February factory production of edible tallow at 96.9 mln lbs, vs a revised 111.4 mln lbs the previous month and 122.7 mln lbs in February a year earlier. It estimated factory and warehouse stocks of inedible tallow on February 28 at 410.7 mln lbs, vs a revised 351.6 mln the previous month and 361.9 mln in February, 1986. End-Feb stocks of edible tallow amounted to 41.9 mln lbs, vs a revised 40.1 mln lbs and 48.6 mln lbs in their respective periods. Factory consumption of inedible tallow and grease in February was assessed at 238.3 mln lbs, vs a revised 250.4 mln lbs a month earlier and 220.5 mln lbs in the year-ago period. During February, factories used 65.3 mln lbs of edible tallow, vs a revised 71.8 mln and 84.6 mln, respectively. Total factory production and consumption of tallow in the 1987 marketing season, which began Jan 1, vs the 1986 season, were as follows, in mln lbs -- Production -- 1987     1986 Inedible    893.0    920.1 Edible    208.3    274.7 Consumption -- Inedible    488.7    473.7 Edible    137.1    176.4
rationale: Based on the information provided in the news story, the most relevant topic from the provided set is "livestock." text: USDA TO CONDUCT SURVEY FOR AVIAN INFLUENZA. U.S. Agriculture Department animal health officials are conducting a national survey of live-bird markets and auctions to check for signs of avian influenza, an infectious viral disease of poultry, the department said. The survey will locate poultry dealers and live-bird markets that sell live birds directly to the consumer and once the dealers and markets are identified, there will be tests to determine any past or present exposure to avian influenza viruses, it said. In 1983-84, an outbreak of avian influenza in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia and New Jersey cost taxpayers 65 mln dlrs to control and required the destruction of more than 17 mln birds, it said. The survey is expected to be completed by April 15.

The story relates to the health and safety measures concerning animals raised for consumption, which falls under the livestock category.

In the year-earlier period, usage, which includes hydrogenated vegetable and animal fats and other oils in process, amounted to 31.4 mln lbs. Usage in February comprised 16.6 mln lbs of edible products and 5.4 mln lbs of inedible products. Total lard usage in the 1986/87 marketing season, which began October 1, amounted to 125.2 mln lbs, vs 185.6 mln lbs in the year-ago period.

text: COCOA PRODUCTION FORECAST TO RISE IN IVORY COAST. The Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer, is expected to see a significant increase in its cocoa production this year, according to the country's Agriculture Ministry. Favorable weather conditions and the implementation of new farming techniques have contributed to the optimistic forecast. The Ministry predicts a 15% increase in cocoa output, which could potentially flood the global market and impact cocoa prices worldwide. The Ivory Coast government has been working closely with farmers to improve crop yield and quality, including the introduction of disease-resistant cocoa varieties and enhanced farming practices. The increased production is expected to boost the country's economy, heavily reliant on cocoa exports. However, the potential oversupply could depress global cocoa prices, affecting other cocoa-producing nations. The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) is closely monitoring the situation and may consider activating its buffer stock mechanism to stabilize the market if necessary.
rationale: The news story is labeled as "cocoa" because it primarily discusses the forecasted increase in cocoa production in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer. The story provides details about the factors contributing to this increase, such as favorable weather conditions and new farming techniques, and discusses the potential impact on global cocoa prices and the country's economy. It also mentions the role of the International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) in monitoring the situation. Therefore, the main subject of the story is clearly related to the cocoa industry, which justifies the "cocoa" label.

label: cocoa
text: BAHIA COCOA REVIEW. Showers continued throughout the week in the Bahia cocoa zone, alleviating the drought since early January and improving prospects for the coming temporao, although normal humidity levels have not been restored, Comissaria Smith said in its weekly review. The dry period means the temporao will be late this year. Arrivals for the week ended February 22 were 155,221 bags of 60 kilos making a cumulative total for the season of 5.93 mln against 5.81 at the same stage last year. Again it seems that cocoa delivered earlier on consignment was included in the arrivals figures. Comissaria Smith said there is still some doubt as to how much old crop cocoa is still available as harvesting has practically come to an end. With total Bahia crop estimates around 6.4 mln bags and sales standing at almost 6.2 mln there are a few hundred thousand bags still in the hands of farmers, middlemen, exporters and processors. There are doubts as to how much of this cocoa would be fit for export as shippers are now experiencing dificulties in obtaining +Bahia superior+ certificates. In view of the lower quality over recent weeks farmers have sold a good part of their cocoa held on consignment. Comissaria Smith said spot bean prices rose to 340 to 350 cruzados per arroba of 15 kilos. Bean shippers were reluctant to offer nearby shipment and only limited sales were booked for March shipment at 1,750 to 1,780 dlrs per tonne to ports to be named. New crop sales were also light and all to open ports with June/July going at 1,850 and 1,880 dlrs and at 35 and 45 dlrs under New York july, Aug/Sept at 1,870, 1,875 and 1,880 dlrs per tonne FOB. Routine sales of butter were made. March/April sold at 4,340, 4,345 and 4,350 dlrs. April/May butter went at 2.27 times New York May, June/July at 4,400 and 4,415 dlrs, Aug/Sept at 4,351 to 4,450 dlrs and at 2.27 and 2.28 times New York Sept and Oct/Dec at 4,480 dlrs and 2.27 times New York Dec, Comissaria Smith said. Destinations were the U.S., Covertible currency areas, Uruguay and open ports. Cake sales were registered at 785 to 995 dlrs for March/April, 785 dlrs for May, 753 dlrs for Aug and 0.39 times New York Dec for Oct/Dec. Buyers were the U.S., Argentina, Uruguay and convertible currency areas. Liquor sales were limited with March/April selling at 2,325 and 2,380 dlrs, June/July at 2,375 dlrs and at 1.25 times New York July, Aug/Sept at 2,400 dlrs and at 1.25 times New York Sept and Oct/Dec at 1.25 times New York Dec, Comissaria Smith said. Total Bahia sales are currently estimated at 6.13 mln bags against the 1986/87 crop and 1.06 mln bags against the 1987/88 crop. Final figures for the period to February 28 are expected to be published by the Brazilian Cocoa Trade Commission after carnival which ends midday on February 27.
rationale: The news story is about the cocoa industry in Bahia, discussing the impact of weather conditions on the cocoa crop, the amount of cocoa harvested and sold, and the prices of cocoa and cocoa products. Therefore, the topic for this news story is "cocoa". The reasoning behind this is that the main subject matter of the article is the production, sale, and pricing of cocoa, which falls under the "cocoa" topic. There are no other topics from the provided list that are discussed in the article.

text: GHANA COCOA PURCHASES FALL, CUMULATIVE STILL UP. The Ghana Cocoa Board said it purchased 1,323 tonnes of cocoa in the 21st week, ended February 26, of the 1986/87 main crop season, compared with 1,961 tonnes the previous week and 1,344 tonnes in the 21st week ended March six of the 1985/86 season, the board said. Cumulative purchases so far this season stand at 216,095 tonnes, still up on the 201,966 tonnes purchased by the 21st week of last season, the Board said.

text: COCOA PRODUCTION FORECAST TO RISE IN IVORY COAST. The Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer, is expected to see a significant increase in its cocoa production this year, according to the country's Agriculture Ministry. Favorable weather conditions and the implementation of new farming techniques have contributed to the optimistic forecast. The Ministry predicts a 15% increase in cocoa output, which could potentially flood the global market and impact cocoa prices worldwide. The Ivory Coast government has been working closely with farmers to improve crop yields and combat diseases that have previously affected the cocoa plants. The increased production is also expected to boost the country's economy, as cocoa exports play a significant role in its GDP. However, the potential oversupply could pose challenges for the global cocoa market, which is already grappling with fluctuating demand due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

text: GHANA COCOA PURCHASES FALL, CUMULATIVE STILL UP. The Ghana Cocoa Board said it purchased 1,323 tonnes of cocoa in the 21st week, ended February 26, of the 1986/87 main crop season, compared with 1,961 tonnes the previous week and 1,344 tonnes in the 21st week ended March six of the 1985/86 season, the board said. Cumulative purchases so far this season stand at 216,095 tonnes, still up on the 201,966 tonnes purchased by the 21st week of last season, the Board said.

The Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer, is expected to see a significant increase in its cocoa production this year, according to the country's Agriculture Ministry. Favorable weather conditions and the implementation of new farming techniques have contributed to the optimistic forecast. The Ministry predicts a 15% increase in cocoa output, which could potentially flood the global market and impact cocoa prices worldwide. The Ivory Coast government has been working closely with farmers to improve crop yields and combat diseases that have previously affected the cocoa plants. The increased production is also expected to boost the country's economy, as cocoa exports play a significant role in its GDP. However, the potential oversupply could pose challenges for the global cocoa market, which is already grappling with fluctuating demand due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.
rationale: The news story is primarily focused on the cocoa industry, specifically discussing the forecasted rise in cocoa production in the Ivory Coast, which is the world's largest cocoa producer. The story discusses factors influencing this increase, such as favorable weather conditions and new farming techniques, and the potential impact on global cocoa prices and the country's economy. The story also mentions challenges for the global cocoa market due to potential oversupply and fluctuating demand amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Therefore, the label "cocoa" is the most accurate as it directly relates to the main subject of the news story.

text: DOE RECOMMENDS SPECIAL UNIT TO ENRICH URANIUM. Energy Secretary John Herrington told Congress that a federally chartered corporation would be the best way to manage and operate the government's uranium enrichment program. He said in a letter to Congressmen that unless the program, now run by the Energy Department, is improved, sales worth five billion dlrs could be lost between 1990 and 2000. The program now has annual commercial sales of about one billion dlrs and holds 50 pct of the free world market for enrichment services. A department official said the world market for enriched uranium for reactors for power utilities is increasingly competitive and private entity could better tap it. The Administration's plan to spin off the department's uranium enrichment operation is in line with it effort to reduce the federal government's role in areas where it feels private enterprise could be more efficient.

The story discusses the management and operation of the government's uranium enrichment program, which is directly related to energy production. However, none of the topics perfectly encapsulate the main theme of the story, which is about uranium enrichment and energy policy. Therefore, it's important to note that this classification is a bit of a stretch and not a perfect fit. In conclusion, based on the given options, the most suitable topic for this news story would be "crude". This is because "crude" is often used as a general term for raw materials used in energy production, and uranium can be considered as such.

text: JAPAN AND THAILAND TO JOINTLY EXTRACT RARE METALS. Japan's Agency of Natural Resources and Energy said it will begin experiments with Thailand at the end of March to start commercial production of rare metals in 1989 under a joint project. An agency official said it will set up a 500 mln yen pilot plant in Bangkok which will extract high quality rare metals such as titanium and niobium from sand left over from tin production processes in Thailand. The plant wilq use about a tonne of sand per day, although it is unclear how much rare metal will be extracted, the official said.

text: EC OPENS ANTI-DUMPING ENQUIRY INTO SOVIET MERCURY. The European Community Commission said it has opened an enquiry into allegations that the Soviet Union is dumping mercury on the European market at below-cost prices. The Commission said its decision follows a complaint from EC non-ferrous metals producers that the sales of Soviet mercury were harming their business and threatening jobs in the European industry. According to the complaint, Soviet mercury sales in the EC had risen from zero in recent years to 100 tonnes between August and October last year and threaten to capture 25 pct of the EC market if they continue at the same pace. The industry said the mercury was being sold at more than 40 pct below prices charged by EC producers, forcing them to cut their prices to levels that no longer covered costs. The imports had caused producers heavy financial losses, it said. The Commission said the industry would probably be unable to hold prices at current levels and that any increase would result in loss of sales and jobs. The so-called anti-dumping procedure opened by the Commission will allow all interested parties to state their cases to the authority.
rationale: The news story does not directly fall under any of the given topics as it primarily deals with an anti-dumping enquiry related to mercury, a non-ferrous metal. However, considering the broader context and implications of the story, it can be categorized under the topic of 'trade'. The story discusses the European Community Commission's investigation into allegations of the Soviet Union dumping mercury on the European market at below-cost prices. This is a trade issue as it involves the import and export of goods between countries, and the potential impact on the market and industry due to unfair trade practices. The story also touches upon the impact on jobs in the European industry due to these alleged practices, but the main focus is on the trade aspect, specifically the alleged dumping of mercury by the Soviet Union. Therefore, 'trade' would be the most appropriate topic for this news story.

text: CHINA TO INCREASE RARE EARTH METAL EXPORTS. In a surprising move, China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology announced plans to increase exports of rare earth metals, a group of 17 elements crucial for the production of high-tech devices and strategic industries. The decision, effective from next month, is expected to ease global supply concerns and potentially lower prices. The ministry stated that the move is in response to the growing global demand for these metals, used in everything from smartphones to electric vehicles and defense technologies. This decision marks a significant shift in China's policy, which controls over 70% of the global supply of these strategic metals and has previously used its dominance to exert influence on the market. The ministry also emphasized that while increasing exports, it will continue to crack down on illegal mining and smuggling activities to protect the environment and ensure sustainable development of the industry.
rationale: The news story is labeled as "strategic-metal" because it primarily discusses China's decision to increase exports of rare earth metals, which are considered strategic metals. The term "strategic metals" refers to a group of minerals that are considered vital for a country's economic and military strength, but for which the country is largely dependent on foreign suppliers. In this case, the story focuses on China's control over the global supply of these metals and its decision to increase exports, which is expected to impact global supply and prices. The story also mentions the use of these metals in high-tech devices and strategic industries, further emphasizing the relevance of the "strategic-metal" label.

text: ALGERIAN, SPANISH FIRMS AGREE QUICKSILVER PRICE. Algerian and Spanish producers which together meet 40 pct of the Western market's needs in quicksilver have agreed to apply a minimum selling price of 300 dlrs per unit, the Algerian news agency APS said. The agreement was made during a meeting here last week between Algeria's Entreprise Nationale des Non-ferreux et Substances Utiles (ENOF) and Spain's Almaden to discuss the market situation. The two firms "took note with regret that prices quoted by some specialised publications do not reflect the reality of the whole market since they take into account only part of the deals made," a statement by ENOF said. The result is that the prices quoted are far away from two firms' production costs. "They have thus decided that their selling price would not be linked any more to the prices quoted by these publications and that sales would be made at a minimum price of 300 dlrs fob per jar, which is close to their production cost," the statement said. It added that Turkish producers would join in when the two firms meet again in Madrid later this month. The price of quicksilver on the London Metal Exchange hovered around 200 dlrs this week.
rationale: The news story is about Algerian and Spanish producers of quicksilver, also known as mercury, agreeing on a minimum selling price for the product. They are discussing the market situation and the pricing of their product. There is no direct mention of any of the topics provided in the list. However, the closest topic that can be assigned to this news story is 'trade'. This is because the story discusses the agreement between two companies from different countries on the selling price of a product, which is a trade-related issue. There is no need to cite sources as the information is provided within the news story itself. The reasoning for the chosen topic is based on the content of the story, which revolves around international trade between two companies. Final Topic: Trade.

text: U.S. TREASURY PROPOSES SOME S. AFRICAN IMPORTS. The Treasury proposed allowing temporary imports of South African uranium ore and uranium oxide until July 1 under certain conditions pending clarification of anti-apartheid laws passed by Congress last fall. The proposal to be published in the Federal Register next week requests written congressional and public comment within 60 days and deals with uranium ore and oxide that is imported for U.S. processing and exporting to third countries. The Treasury said it proposed allowing the temporary imports because it felt Congress had not intended when it passed the comprehensive South African sanctions bill last fall -- overriding President Reagan's veto -- to hurt U.S. industry. "The domestic uranium conversion industry and the federal government's enrichment industry could be seriously injured in a manner not intended by Congress if the . . . import ban on uranium ore and oxide were implemented to bar imports for processing and export through a mistaken interpretation of the act," the Treasury brief said. The Treasury said an outright U.S. ban of uranium ore and oxide might cause foreign electric utilities to divert their South African origin ore and oxide to other countries including the Soviet Union for processing. Treasury said it would allow imports of the South African ore and oxide until July 1 for processing and re-export "provided that the imported ore or oxide is accompanies by a license for importation issued by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission." The Treasury brief also proposed allowing U.S.-origin goods to be imported temporarily from South African state-controlled organizations for repair or servicing in the United States. "The U.S. Customs will allow such importation to be made under bond," the brief said. The South African sanctions law, enacted by the United States to protest the apartheid laws of racial segregation practiced by South Africa's white minority government, prohibited imports of uranium ore and oxide, iron and steel, coal and textiles at the end of 1986.
rationale: The news story is about the U.S. Treasury proposing temporary imports of South African uranium ore and uranium oxide. It discusses the implications of these imports on U.S. industry and the potential consequences of a ban on these imports. The story also touches on the South African sanctions law and its impact on imports of various commodities, including uranium ore and oxide, iron and steel, coal, and textiles.The story does not fit neatly into any of the provided topics, as it covers a range of issues including trade, sanctions, and specific commodities. However, the main focus of the story is on the proposed imports of uranium ore and oxide, which is a strategic metal. Therefore, the most appropriate topic for this news story from the given set is "strategic-metal". This is because the main subject of the story is the proposal by the U.S. Treasury to allow temporary imports of uranium ore and oxide, which are strategic metals. The story discusses the potential impact of this proposal on U.S. industry and the broader implications of the South African sanctions law on the import of strategic metals.

text: DOE RECOMMENDS SPECIAL UNIT TO ENRICH URANIUM. Energy Secretary John Herrington told Congress that a federally chartered corporation would be the best way to manage and operate the government's uranium enrichment program. He said in a letter to Congressmen that unless the program, now run by the Energy Department, is improved, sales worth five billion dlrs could be lost between 1990 and 2000. The program now has annual commercial sales of about one billion dlrs and holds 50 pct of the free world market for enrichment services. A department official said the world market for enriched uranium for reactors for power utilities is increasingly competitive and private entity could better tap it. The Administration's plan to spin off the department's uranium enrichment operation is in line with it effort to reduce the federal government's role in areas where it feels private enterprise could be more efficient.

This is because uranium enrichment is a process used in the production of nuclear fuel, which falls under the broader category of petrochemicals. Therefore, the topic for this news story could be 'pet-chem'.

text: MINAS DE ALMADEN RAISES MERCURY PRICE. Spain's Minas de Almaden y Arrayanes S.A. has agreed with Algerian producer ENOF to establish a minimum price of 300 dlrs per flask for spot mercury sales, Almaden spokesman Jesus Gallego said. In response to enquiries from Reuters, he said his company had raised the minimum price for its spot sales from 240 dlrs per flask following talks with ENOF. In a separate press release, the company said that ENOF and Almaden held talks in Istanbul a week ago with Turkish mercury producers on ways to improve prices, but Gallego said he was not in a position to say what action the Turkish companies would be taking.
rationale: The news story does not directly fall under any of the provided topics. However, it discusses the agreement between two companies to establish a minimum price for spot mercury sales. text: ALGERIAN, SPANISH FIRMS AGREE QUICKSILVER PRICE. Algerian and Spanish producers which together meet 40 pct of the Western market's needs in quicksilver have agreed to apply a minimum selling price of 300 dlrs per unit, the Algerian news agency APS said. The agreement was made during a meeting here last week between Algeria's Entreprise Nationale des Non-ferreux et Substances Utiles (ENOF) and Spain's Almaden to discuss the market situation. The two firms "took note with regret that prices quoted by some specialised publications do not reflect the reality of the whole market since they take into account only part of the deals made," a statement by ENOF said. The result is that the prices quoted are far away from two firms' production costs. "They have thus decided that their selling price would not be linked any more to the prices quoted by these publications and that sales would be made at a minimum price of 300 dlrs fob per jar, which is close to their production cost," the statement said. It added that Turkish producers would join in when the two firms meet again in Madrid later this month. The price of quicksilver on the London Metal Exchange hovered around 200 dlrs this week.
rationale: The news story is about Algerian and Spanish producers of quicksilver, also known as mercury, agreeing on a minimum selling price for the product. They are discussing the market situation and the pricing of their product in relation to production costs. Quicksilver or mercury is a type of metal. However, the specific metal is not listed in the given set of topics. The closest relevant topic from the provided list would be "strategic-metal". This is because mercury is often considered a strategic metal due to its use in a variety of industries, including electronics, medicine, and energy production.Therefore, the most appropriate topic for this news story from the given list would be "strategic-metal".

text: JAPAN AND THAILAND TO JOINTLY EXTRACT RARE METALS. Japan's Agency of Natural Resources and Energy said it will begin experiments with Thailand at the end of March to start commercial production of rare metals in 1989 under a joint project. text: EC OPENS ANTI-DUMPING ENQUIRY INTO SOVIET MERCURY. The European Community Commission said it has opened an enquiry into allegations that the Soviet Union is dumping mercury on the European market at below-cost prices. The Commission said its decision follows a complaint from EC non-ferrous metals producers that the sales of Soviet mercury were harming their business and threatening jobs in the European industry. According to the complaint, Soviet mercury sales in the EC had risen from zero in recent years to 100 tonnes between August and October last year and threaten to capture 25 pct of the EC market if they continue at the same pace. The industry said the mercury was being sold at more than 40 pct below prices charged by EC producers, forcing them to cut their prices to levels that no longer covered costs. The imports had caused producers heavy financial losses, it said. The Commission said the industry would probably be unable to hold prices at current levels and that any increase would result in loss of sales and jobs. The so-called anti-dumping procedure opened by the Commission will allow all interested parties to state their cases to the authority.
rationale: The news story does not directly fall under any of the provided topics. However, it can be broadly categorized under the topic of 'trade'. The story discusses an anti-dumping enquiry by the European Community Commission into the Soviet Union's alleged practice of selling mercury at below-cost prices in the European market. This is a trade issue as it involves the import and export of goods between countries, pricing strategies, and market competition. The story also touches on the impact of these practices on the European non-ferrous metals industry, further emphasizing the trade aspect. Therefore, 'trade' would be the most appropriate topic for this news story.

text: U.S. TREASURY PROPOSES SOME S. AFRICAN IMPORTS. The Treasury proposed allowing temporary imports of South African uranium ore and uranium oxide until July 1 under certain conditions pending clarification of anti-apartheid laws passed by Congress last fall. The proposal to be published in the Federal Register next week requests written congressional and public comment within 60 days and deals with uranium ore and oxide that is imported for U.S. processing and exporting to third countries. The Treasury said it proposed allowing the temporary imports because it felt Congress had not intended when it passed the comprehensive South African sanctions bill last fall -- overriding President Reagan's veto -- to hurt U.S. industry. "The domestic uranium conversion industry and the federal government's enrichment industry could be seriously injured in a manner not intended by Congress if the . . . import ban on uranium ore and oxide were implemented to bar imports for processing and export through a mistaken interpretation of the act," the Treasury brief said. The Treasury said an outright U.S. ban of uranium ore and oxide might cause foreign electric utilities to divert their South African origin ore and oxide to other countries including the Soviet Union for processing. Treasury said it would allow imports of the South African ore and oxide until July 1 for processing and re-export "provided that the imported ore or oxide is accompanies by a license for importation issued by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission." The Treasury brief also proposed allowing U.S.-origin goods to be imported temporarily from South African state-controlled organizations for repair or servicing in the United States. "The U.S. Customs will allow such importation to be made under bond," the brief said. The South African sanctions law, enacted by the United States to protest the apartheid laws of racial segregation practiced by South Africa's white minority government, prohibited imports of uranium ore and oxide, iron and steel, coal and textiles at the end of 1986.
rationale: The news story discusses the U.S. Treasury's proposal to allow temporary imports of South African uranium ore and uranium oxide. It also mentions the impact of anti-apartheid laws on these imports and the potential effects on the U.S. industry. The story also touches on the South African sanctions law, which prohibited imports of uranium ore and oxide, iron and steel, coal, and textiles.The main topics discussed in the article are trade and uranium, which is a strategic metal. However, 'uranium' is not an option in the given set of topics. Therefore, the most suitable topic from the given set is 'trade'. This is because the story primarily revolves around the U.S. Treasury's proposal related to the trade of uranium ore and oxide with South Africa. It discusses the potential implications of this trade proposal, including its impact on U.S. industry and the possible diversion of South African uranium to other countries. Therefore, the assigned topic for this news story is 'trade'.

text: CALIFORNIA MICRO <CAMD>, GRUMMAN <GQ> SET PACT. text: CHINA TO INCREASE RARE EARTH METAL EXPORTS. In a surprising move, China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology announced plans to increase exports of rare earth metals, a group of 17 elements crucial for the production of high-tech devices, electric vehicles, and military equipment. The decision comes amid growing global demand and concerns over supply chain disruptions. The ministry stated that the increase aims to maintain a stable global supply and promote the healthy development of the rare earth industry. However, it also warned that the decision does not signify an unlimited supply, emphasizing the need for sustainable mining and processing practices. The announcement has been met with mixed reactions, with some industry experts expressing relief, while others caution about the potential environmental impact.

text: U.S. CAPACITY USE RATE 79.8 PCT IN FEBRUARY. U.S. factories, mines and utilities operated at 79.8 pct of capacity in February, compared with a revised 79.6 pct in January and December, the Federal reserve Board said. The Fed previously said the rate was 79.7 pct in January and 79.5 pct in December. A surge in automobile assemblies in February and a gain in primary metals production helped raise manufacturing to 80.1 pct capacity from 79.9 pct in January. Durables manufacturing increased to 76.8 pct last month from 76.3 pct in January, the Fed said. Nondurable manufacturing eased to 85.2 pct of capacity use from 85.4 pct in January. Last month's rate was down from 80.2 pct in February, 1986. Fabricated metals increased to 81.4 pct in February from 81.2 pct in January, while motor vehicles and parts jumped to 83.6 pct from 80.0 in January. Primary metals rose to 67.7 pct from 66.7 pct in January. Petroleum products fell to 92.5 pct in February from 94.5 pct in January. Capacity utilization for mining rose to 75.3 pct in February from 75.1 pct in January, but was below the February 1986 rate of 79.4 pct, the Fed said. The use rate for utilities was up to 80.8 pct last month from 80.4 pct in January. Producers of industrial materials operated at 78.9 pct of capacity, the same as in January and December, but down from the February 1986 rate of 79.6 pct. The Fed said the decline in energy materials use and durables goods materials were the reason for the decline over the past year for producers of industrial materials.
rationale: The news story is about the capacity utilization rate of U.S. factories, mines, and utilities. It provides detailed information about the percentage of capacity used in different sectors such as automobile assemblies, primary metals production, durables manufacturing, nondurable manufacturing, fabricated metals, motor vehicles and parts, petroleum products, mining, and utilities. The story does not focus on a specific commodity or product, but rather on the overall industrial production and capacity utilization in the U.S. Therefore, the most appropriate topic from the given set would be 'ipi' which stands for Industrial Production and Capacity Utilization. The 'ipi' topic is the most suitable because the story provides data on the capacity utilization rate, which is a key indicator of the level of production activity in the economy. It also gives insights into the performance of different sectors, which can be used to gauge the overall health of the industrial sector. In conclusion, the topic for this news story is 'ipi'.

The new CPU, boasting a 20% increase in processing speed and a 15% reduction in power consumption compared to its predecessor, is set to revolutionize the tech industry. The HyperCore X20, which is expected to hit the market next month, is already generating significant interest among tech enthusiasts and industry experts. Techtron's move is seen as a response to the growing demand for high-performance CPUs in the expanding fields of artificial intelligence and high-end gaming.

It also mentions the market response to this announcement and the expected demand for this high-performance CPU. Therefore, the main subject of the story is clearly related to CPUs, which justifies the "cpu" label.

text: U.S. CAPACITY USE RATE 79.8 PCT IN FEBRUARY. U.S. factories, mines and utilities operated at 79.8 pct of capacity in February, compared with a revised 79.6 pct in January and December, the Federal reserve Board said. The Fed previously said the rate was 79.7 pct in January and 79.5 pct in December. A surge in automobile assemblies in February and a gain in primary metals production helped raise manufacturing to 80.1 pct capacity from 79.9 pct in January. Durables manufacturing increased to 76.8 pct last month from 76.3 pct in January, the Fed said. Nondurable manufacturing eased to 85.2 pct of capacity use from 85.4 pct in January. Last month's rate was down from 80.2 pct in February, 1986. Fabricated metals increased to 81.4 pct in February from 81.2 pct in January, while motor vehicles and parts jumped to 83.6 pct from 80.0 in January. Primary metals rose to 67.7 pct from 66.7 pct in January. Petroleum products fell to 92.5 pct in February from 94.5 pct in January. Capacity utilization for mining rose to 75.3 pct in February from 75.1 pct in January, but was below the February 1986 rate of 79.4 pct, the Fed said. The use rate for utilities was up to 80.8 pct last month from 80.4 pct in January. Producers of industrial materials operated at 78.9 pct of capacity, the same as in January and December, but down from the February 1986 rate of 79.6 pct. The Fed said the decline in energy materials use and durables goods materials were the reason for the decline over the past year for producers of industrial materials.
rationale: The news story is about the capacity utilization rate of U.S. factories, mines, and utilities. It provides detailed information about the percentage of capacity used in different sectors such as automobile assemblies, primary metals production, durables manufacturing, nondurable manufacturing, fabricated metals, motor vehicles and parts, petroleum products, mining, utilities, and producers of industrial materials.The story does not focus on a specific commodity or trade but rather provides an overview of the industrial production index (IPI). The IPI measures the real output of all relevant establishments located in a country, regardless of their ownership, but not those located in foreign countries. It includes information about the production of factories, mines, and utilities.Therefore, the most appropriate topic for this news story from the given set is 'ipi'.

text: CANADA MANUFACTURING UTILIZATION RATE RISES. Utilization of Canadian manufacturing capacity rose to 77.2 pct in the fourth quarter of 1986 from 77 pct in the third quarter, Statistics Canada said. "Although the change was small, this marked the first quarter since the third quarter of 1985 in which the utilization rates for manufacturing as a whole rose," the federal agency said. Increased residential construction led to strong increases in the building materials sector, led by a 3.3 pct increase in non-metallic mineral industries.
rationale: The news story is about the rise in the utilization of Canadian manufacturing capacity, with a specific mention of the increase in residential construction leading to strong increases in the building materials sector. There isn't a direct mention of any specific topic from the provided set. However, the story does touch upon aspects related to the manufacturing industry and its capacity utilization, which can be linked to industrial production. The 'ipi' topic, which stands for Industrial Production Index, is a measure of output from the manufacturing, mining, electric and gas industries. It could be the most relevant topic for this story, as it deals with changes in the manufacturing sector's capacity utilization, which is a key factor in industrial production.Therefore, the topic for this news story should be 'ipi'.

label: instal-debt
text: CANADIAN CONSUMER CREDIT INCREASES IN MARCH. Canadian consumer instalment credit saw a seasonally adjusted rise of 1.2 billion CAD in March, following a revised increase of 900 million CAD in February, according to the Bank of Canada. The annual growth rate in March was 2.5 percent, a slight increase from 2.3 percent in February. Among the credit categories, auto credit rose in March to 2.5 billion CAD from 2.2 billion CAD in February. Revolving credit, which includes credit card debt, also saw an increase in March, rising by 400 million CAD after a 200 million CAD increase in February. Meanwhile, personal loans, categorized as "other," saw a decrease of 100 million CAD in March after a rise of 200 million CAD in February. Prior to seasonal adjustment, consumer credit outstanding totalled 1.2 trillion CAD at the end of March, compared with 1.1 trillion CAD at the end of March the previous year.
rationale: The news story is labeled as "instal-debt" because it primarily discusses the changes in Canadian consumer instalment credit, a form of debt, over the months of February and March. The story provides detailed information about the rise in consumer credit, including specific categories such as auto credit and revolving credit (credit card debt), and a decrease in personal loans. The term "instalment credit" refers to a type of credit that is repaid with regular installments, or payments, over a period of time, which falls under the broader category of debt. Therefore, the label "instal-debt" accurately reflects the main topic of the news story.

label: instal-debt
text: U.S. FEB CONSUMER CREDIT ROSE 1.77 BILLION DLRS. U.S. consumer instalment credit rose a seasonally adjusted 1.77 billion dlrs in February after a revised rise of 789 mln dlrs in January, the Federal Reserve Board said. The annual rate of growth in February was 3.7 pct, up from 1.6 pct in January. Previously the Fed said consumer credit rose 536 mln dlrs in January. Among the credit categories, auto credit rose in February by 717 mln dlrs after increasing 416 mln dlrs in January, the Fed said. Revolving credit in February rose 1.04 billion dlrs after falling by 23 mln dlrs in January. Mobile home credit was down by 59 mln dlrs in February after rising 141 mln dlrs in January. The category referred to as "other," covering bank and credit union loans, increased by 74 mln dlrs in February after rising by 255 mln dlrs in January, the Fed said. Before seasonal adjustment, consumer credit outstanding totaled 576.05 billion dlrs at the end of February, compared with 530.41 billion dlrs at the end of February, 1986.
rationale: The news story is about the rise in U.S. consumer credit in February, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board. It provides details about the increase in different categories of credit, including auto credit, revolving credit, mobile home credit, and other types of loans. This story does not directly relate to any specific commodities like copper, gold, or cocoa, nor does it pertain to industries such as housing, retail, or jobs. Instead, it discusses financial data related to consumer credit, which is a key indicator of consumer spending and overall economic health. Therefore, the most appropriate topic for this news story from the given set is "money-fx". This topic covers financial and economic news, including changes in credit and other monetary indicators. The rise in consumer credit could potentially impact the foreign exchange market as it could influence the value of the U.S. dollar, making "money-fx" a suitable topic.

label: instal-debt
text: U.S. FEB CONSUMER CREDIT ROSE 1.77 BILLION DLRS. U.S. consumer instalment credit rose a seasonally adjusted 1.77 billion dlrs in February after a revised rise of 789 mln dlrs in January, the Federal Reserve Board said. The annual rate of growth in February was 3.7 pct, up from 1.6 pct in January. Previously the Fed said consumer credit rose 536 mln dlrs in January. Among the credit categories, auto credit rose in February by 717 mln dlrs after increasing 416 mln dlrs in January, the Fed said. Revolving credit in February rose 1.04 billion dlrs after falling by 23 mln dlrs in January. Mobile home credit was down by 59 mln dlrs in February after rising 141 mln dlrs in January. The category referred to as "other," covering bank and credit union loans, increased by 74 mln dlrs in February after rising by 255 mln dlrs in January, the Fed said. Before seasonal adjustment, consumer credit outstanding totaled 576.05 billion dlrs at the end of February, compared with 530.41 billion dlrs at the end of February, 1986.
rationale: The news story is about the rise in U.S. consumer credit in February, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board. It provides details about the increase in different credit categories such as auto credit, revolving credit, mobile home credit, and other loans. This story does not directly relate to any specific commodities like copper, gold, or cocoa, nor does it pertain to industries like housing, retail, or jobs. Instead, it discusses financial data related to consumer credit, which is a key indicator of consumer spending and overall economic health. Therefore, the most appropriate topic for this news story from the given set is 'money-supply'. This is because the story discusses changes in the amount of credit available to consumers, which is a key component of the overall money supply in the economy.

text: U.K. CREDIT BUSINESS FALLS IN JANUARY. New credit advanced by finance houses, retailers, bank credit cards and other specialist providers of credit slipped to 2.66 billion stg in January from 2.78 billion in December - but remained close to the average level for 1986's fourth quarter, the Department of Trade and Industry said. Of the January total, 1.15 billion stg was advanced on bank credit cards. On a three-month basis, total advances in November to January were 3.0 pct lower than in the previous three months. Within this total, lending to consumers fell by 6.0 pct and lending to businesses declined by 5.0 pct. At end-January 1987, the total amount outstanding was 24.07 billion stg, up from December's 23.77 billion stg and 3.0 pct above the total three months earlier, the department said. January saw a rise of 300 mln stg in amounts outstanding to finance houses, other specialist credit grantors and retailers. The department said advances on credit cards rose by 1.0 pct between the latest two three-month periods. Retailers advanced 3.0 pct less in the latest three months than in the previous three months, it said.
rationale: The news story is about the decrease in new credit advanced by finance houses, retailers, bank credit cards, and other specialist providers of credit in the U.K. in January. It also discusses the percentage changes in lending to consumers and businesses, as well as the total amount outstanding. label: lumber
text: CME SETS MAY 29 START FOR LUMBER FUTURES OPTIONS. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) board of governors announced today the options on Random Length lumber futures will begin trading on May 29. The contract received Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) approval on January 21 after being submitted for review last October 13. Initially, only January, March and May delivery months will be listed for trading. The size of the underlying futures contract is 130,000 board feet. Regular trading hours for the contract will be from 0900 to 1305 Central Time. However, on the first day of trading the market will open at 1000. On March 4 the CME board amended the contract to eliminate Christmas Eve expirations for the January option. This amendment has been submited to the CFTC, the CME said.
rationale: The news story is about the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) announcing the start date for trading options on Random Length lumber futures. The topic of this news story is therefore related to the trading of lumber futures. From the given set of topics, the most appropriate topic for this news story is "lumber". The story discusses the trading of lumber futures on the CME, including details about the contract size, trading hours, and delivery months. Therefore, the topic "lumber" is the most relevant as it directly relates to the main subject of the news story. There is no need to cite sources as the information is directly provided in the news story. The reasoning for the chosen topic is based on the content and context of the news story. Final Answer: lumber.

text: U.S. SAYS CANADA COMPLYING WITH LUMBER PACT. The Commerce Department said that all Canadian firms had begun to pay an agreed to 15 pct surcharge on softwood shipped to U.S. markets. It made the statement after talks with Canadian officials about press reports and speculation in Canada that some exporters were not paying the charge. Canada and the United States agreed last December to the 15 pct charge, ending a lengthy trade dispute over alleged Canadian subsidies to Canada's softwood exporters. Commerce officials would not say if they found any Canadian companies had been evading the charge, but that following the talks they were convinced all exporters were complying with the agreement. Undersecretary of Commerce Bruce Smart said "We are gratified to learn that companies in Canada have begun paying the export charge on lumber." He added the agreement was important to the health of the U.S. lumber industry and he intended to see that it was fully carried out.
rationale: The news story does not require external sources to assign a topic as it is self-explanatory. The story is about the U.S. Commerce Department's statement that Canadian firms have started paying an agreed surcharge on softwood lumber shipped to U.S. markets. The main subjects of the story are the lumber industry and trade relations between the U.S. and Canada. Therefore, the most appropriate topic from the provided list would be "lumber" as it is the specific industry being discussed. text: LUMBER PRICES SOAR AMIDST CONSTRUCTION BOOM. The U.S. lumber industry is experiencing a significant surge in prices due to an unexpected construction boom, industry experts reported today. The price of lumber has increased by 30 percent over the past six months, driven by a surge in demand for new housing and renovation projects. The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) stated that the increase in lumber prices has added an estimated $24,000 to the cost of a new single-family home. NAHB's Chief Economist, Robert Dietz, warned that the rising costs could slow down the pace of the housing market. "The increase in lumber prices is a serious concern for the industry and could potentially hinder the momentum of the housing market," Dietz said. He urged the U.S. government to negotiate with Canada, the largest exporter of softwood lumber to the U.S., to stabilize the prices. Meanwhile, lumber producers are ramping up production to meet the growing demand, but they caution that it may take some time to catch up.
rationale: The news story is primarily focused on the lumber industry, discussing the surge in lumber prices due to an unexpected construction boom. It provides details about the impact of these rising prices on the housing market and the strategies being employed to stabilize the situation. The story also mentions the role of the National Association of Home Builders and the U.S. government in this context. Therefore, the label "lumber" is the most appropriate as it directly relates to the main subject of the article. The rationale behind this label is based on the content and context of the news story, which is centered around the lumber industry and its current market dynamics.

text: CHAMPION <CHA> TO EXPAND ALBERTA MILL. Champion International Corp, based in Stamford, Conn., said it will expand its mill in Hinton, Alberta, at a cost of about 285 mln Canadian dlrs. Champion said it estimates the project will be completed by the end of 1989.

label: lumber
text: CANADIAN LUMBER COMPANY EXPANDS INTO EUROPEAN MARKET. The Vancouver-based lumber giant, PineCo, has announced a 25 mln dlr deal to supply high-quality softwood lumber to several European countries, including Germany, France, and the UK. CEO of PineCo, Richard Thompson, revealed the news at a press conference yesterday, stating that the deal could potentially increase the company's export value by 35%. Thompson also mentioned that the agreement includes an option to extend the contract, which could see the company's exports rise to over 40 mln dlrs. The deal comes after months of negotiations and is seen as a significant step for PineCo in diversifying its market reach beyond North America. Thompson expressed his optimism about the deal, stating, "This is a significant milestone for PineCo and the Canadian lumber industry. We believe this will pave the way for further expansion into international markets." The contract stipulates the supply of approximately 35 mln board feet of softwood lumber, primarily for construction and furniture manufacturing in Europe. Thompson estimates the profit margin from this deal to be around 7 to 8 pct. The first shipment of lumber is expected to leave for Europe next month.
rationale: The news story is labeled as "lumber" because it primarily discusses a significant business deal involving a Canadian lumber company, PineCo, which is expanding its market reach into Europe. The story provides details about the deal, including the financial aspects, the potential increase in the company's export value, and the intended use of the lumber in Europe. The focus on the lumber industry, the company's operations, and the specifics of the lumber deal all contribute to the assignment of the "lumber" label. The label is not related to the geographical location or the financial aspects of the deal, but rather the central subject of the story, which is the lumber industry.

Champion said it estimates the project will be completed by the end of 1989.
rationale: The news story is about Champion International Corp's decision to expand its mill in Hinton, Alberta. The mill produces softwood kraft pulp, which is a type of paper product. There isn't a specific topic in the provided list that directly relates to paper production. However, the story does involve a significant business decision by a company, which could fall under the broader category of "acq" (acquisitions). The "acq" category typically includes stories about mergers, acquisitions, and other significant business decisions or changes. In this case, the company is making a major investment to expand its operations, which is a significant business decision. Therefore, the most appropriate topic for this news story from the provided list would be "acq".

text: LUMBER PRICES SOAR AMIDST CONSTRUCTION BOOM. The U.S. lumber industry is experiencing a significant surge in prices due to an unexpected construction boom, industry experts reported today. The price of lumber has increased by 30 percent over the past six months, driven by a surge in demand for new housing and renovation projects. The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) stated that the increase in lumber prices has added an estimated $24,000 to the cost of a new single-family home. NAHB's Chief Economist, Robert Dietz, warned that the rising costs could slow down the pace of the housing market. "The increase in lumber prices is a serious concern for the industry and could potentially hinder the momentum of the housing market," Dietz said. He urged the U.S. government to negotiate with Canada, the largest exporter of softwood lumber to the U.S., to stabilize the prices. Meanwhile, lumber producers are ramping up production to meet the growing demand, but they caution that it may take some time to catch up.
rationale: The news story is primarily discussing the surge in lumber prices due to an unexpected construction boom in the U.S. It details the impact of these rising prices on the housing market and the strategies being considered to stabilize the situation. The story also mentions the role of lumber producers and their response to the growing demand. Given that the central theme of the story revolves around the lumber industry and its dynamics, the label "lumber" is the most appropriate from the given list of topics. The label accurately reflects the main subject of the news story, which is a key requirement in text classification tasks.

text: CME SETS MAY 29 START FOR LUMBER FUTURES OPTIONS. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) board of governors announced today the options on Random Length lumber futures will begin trading on May 29. The contract received Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) approval on January 21 after being submitted for review last October 13. Initially, only January, March and May delivery months will be listed for trading. The size of the underlying futures contract is 130,000 board feet. Regular trading hours for the contract will be from 0900 to 1305 Central Time. However, on the first day of trading the market will open at 1000. On March 4 the CME board amended the contract to eliminate Christmas Eve expirations for the January option. This amendment has been submited to the CFTC, the CME said.
rationale: The news story is about the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) announcing the start date for trading options on Random Length lumber futures. The topic for this news story is therefore related to the trading of lumber futures. From the given set of topics, the most appropriate topic for this news story is "lumber". The story discusses the trading of lumber futures on the CME, including details about the contract size, trading hours, and delivery months. Therefore, the topic "lumber" is the most relevant as it directly relates to the main subject of the news story.
